head.title: Back in Town With a Voice Both Polished And Profound

hedline.hl1: Back in Town With a Voice Both Polished And Profound

abstract.p: Stephen Holden reviews performance by singer Polly Bergen at Feinstein's at the Regency; photo (M)

block.p: Every interpretive singer must decide how to balance the desire to sound beautiful with the quest for dramatic truthfulness, and in this age of mass cosmetic surgery a glossy vocal finish increasingly cancels out the divulging of an inner life. Yet a few singers still know how to balance that equation. And in her first New York nightclub appearance in 35 years, Polly Bergen is a triumphant example of a singer having her cake and eating it, too. Ms. Bergen's opening night show on Tuesday at Feinstein's at the Regency, where she is appearing through Oct. 21, was, in a word, great.

It was 1957 when Ms. Bergen became an overnight sensation portraying the torch singer Helen Morgan in a television biography. And her recordings from that period showcase a lush pop contralto with some raw edges guided by a brash, extroverted personality that delivered lyrics with directness that sometimes bordered on impatience. Even when singing a mournful song, Ms. Bergen still sounded on top of it all.

Ms. Bergen's opening night show on Tuesday at Feinstein's at the Regency, where she is appearing through Oct. 21, was, in a word, great.

It was 1957 when Ms. Bergen became an overnight sensation portraying the torch singer Helen Morgan in a television biography. And her recordings from that period showcase a lush pop contralto with some raw edges guided by a brash, extroverted personality that delivered lyrics with directness that sometimes bordered on impatience. Even when singing a mournful song, Ms. Bergen still sounded on top of it all.

Her voice on Tuesday was in fine shape, with its rich lower register intact, and her enunciation was as letter-perfect as ever. What has changed is her willingness to put her life on the line with every song, digging into the lyrics and imparting a personal emotional resonance to every phrase.

Among contemporary cabaret singers, only that ageless bird of paradise, Julie Wilson, invests song lyrics with a comparable sense of drama. And what Ms. Bergen conveys in numbers like ''Stars'' (Janis Ian's extended reflection on the shallowness of fame) and ''The Ladies Who Lunch'' is a complex mixture of rage, strength, vulnerability and the thorny good-natured humor of someone who knows the score.

More than 40 years after Ms. Bergen first recorded Morgan's signature song, ''Why Was I Born?,'' her present-day version, done as a medley with ''Bill,'' poses the title question with utmost seriousness, then answers it with a humble, no-frills declaration of love. A medley of ''Here's That Rainy Day'' and ''Where's the Boy I Saved for a Rainy Day?'' plumbs the depths of heartbreak and loneliness, while the country-flavored ''He Ain't Mr. Right'' rides a current of sexy humor without turning cheap.
The ultimate impression left by the show is a portrait of a woman who has led the glamorous life and somehow not lost her humanity.
